did.abstract: Collection consists of letters from Hall writing home to his family, containing comments on Civil War campaigns and battles in North Carolina and Virginia, conscription and the draft, African American regiments, army life, and equipment and supplies. Hall describes Camp Buckingham (Jamaica, Long Island); the battles of Roanoke and Newburn; marching through North Carolina to Fort Macon; joining the Army of the Potomac; the battles of South Mountain and Antietam; the Union occupations of Suffolk and Portsmouth; his participation in court martials for military criminals; and his fighting during the seige on Petersburg. Hall includes his regiment's favorable opinions of General Burnside and General Grant, and records that the men disliked George McClellan.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Henry Hall was a captain in the 8th Connecticut Volunteers, U.S. Army during the Civil War; he was originally from Danbury (Fairfield Co.), Conn., and enlisted in the army in September 1861.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of letters from Hall writing home to his family, containing comments on Civil War campaigns and battles in North Carolina and Virginia, conscription and the draft, African American regiments, army life, and equipment and supplies. Hall describes Camp Buckingham (Jamaica, Long Island); the battles of Roanoke and Newburn; marching through North Carolina to Fort Macon; joining the Army of the Potomac; the battles of South Mountain and Antietam; the Union occupations of Suffolk and Portsmouth; his participation in court martials for military criminals; and his fighting during the seige on Petersburg. Hall includes his regiment's favorable opinions of General Burnside and General Grant, and records that the men disliked George McClellan.
